headline: Most popular websites for news in the world: Monthly top 50 listing
context: American and Canadian political and hard news sites were among the biggest year-on-year web traffic gainers in the world in March 2025 amid a turbulent start to the second Trump administration.

Strong growth from the New York Times, coupled with a change in methodology from Similarweb, means it has overtaken the BBC to become number one on Press Gazette’s ranking of the top-50 English language news websites worldwide.

annotations.paragraph: The Associated Press (148 million visits, up 64% year-on-year), Reuters (111.4 million, up 54%) and Politico (53.5 million, up 29%) saw the second, fourth and fifth largest increases to their web visits respectively compared to March 2024.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on traffic increases for major news sites, relevant to the ranking.

annotations.paragraph: Only Indian news site India.com (132.7 million, up 86%) saw more growth over the year. Publishing platform Substack, which has become home to numerous small political writing outlets, saw the third most growth, rising 54% year-on-year to 116.9 million visits.
annotations.reason: Offers specific growth data for India.com and Substack, relevant to the ranking.

annotations.paragraph: The picture was not straightforwardly one of growth across the 50 most-visited English-language news sites in the world, with half losing traffic compared to March 2024. However 11 managed to grow their visits by 10% or more, and of them eight by at least 20%.
annotations.reason: Provides context on overall traffic trends among the top 50 sites, relevant to the ranking.

annotations.paragraph: Among the ten most-visited sites specifically, seven grew their traffic, with People magazine (195.9 million, up 11% year-on-year) the biggest beneficiary. It was followed by The New York Times 680.5 million, up 6%), Yahoo Finance (248.5 million, up 5%) and BBC News (678.6 million, up 4%).
annotations.reason: Gives specific traffic data for the top ten sites, relevant to the ranking.

annotations.paragraph: March marks a change in the way Press Gazette and Similarweb calculate the BBC’s global traffic. Previously we added together global traffic to the bbc.co.uk to determine the organisation’s total visits. However, Similarweb has now advised that because visits to bbc.com outside the US are redirected to bbc.co.uk, this likely double-counts some traffic.
annotations.reason: Explains a methodological change affecting the ranking, relevant to understanding the data.

annotations.paragraph: As a result, from this month we are calculating the BBC’s world traffic by adding the global bbc.co.uk figure to the US bbc.com figure. This means that the BBC has dropped from clear first place, with more than one billion visits per month, to an extremely close second behind The New York Times.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides essential context about the change in methodology affecting the BBC's ranking.

annotations.paragraph: Month-on-month every news site in the English-language top ten saw traffic grow by at least 5%, with the fact March is 11% longer than February a contributing factor.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about traffic growth trends among top news sites.

annotations.paragraph: The greatest growth was at The Guardian (334.8 million, up 11% compared with February), followed by the NYT (also up 11%), Yahoo Finance (248.5 million, up 9%) and Google News (342.8 million, up 9%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on traffic growth for major news sites.

annotations.paragraph: Among the broader top 50 all but 11 sites saw month-on-month growth, with the biggest increase seen at American business publisher CNBC (140.6 million, up 30%). It was followed by Newsweek (115.2 million, up 26%), Business Insider (83.7 million, up 23%) and Australia’s ABC (72.9 million, up 20%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides detailed information on traffic growth for a range of news sites.

annotations.paragraph: Despite India.com’s year-on-year success, Indian news sites generally were among the biggest fallers in March both year-on-year and month-on-month.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about the performance of Indian news sites.

annotations.paragraph: There were 11 Indian news sites in the global top 50 in March, many of which have risen up the ranking in the last two years. Six saw month-on-month traffic drop and nine saw a fall year-on-year.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about the performance of Indian news sites in the global ranking.

annotations.paragraph: The sharpest year-on-year decline at any top 50 site came at India’s livemint.com (53.9 million, down 43%), followed by Indian site News18 (163.4 million, down 33%), UK tabloid The Sun (56.2 million, down 32%) and India Today (71 million, down 29%).
annotations.reason: Details specific declines in traffic for certain news sites, contributing to the overall analysis of the rankings.

annotations.paragraph: Continue reading for previous months’ coverage of the world’s top 50 websites for news:
annotations.reason: Serves as a prompt for further reading and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: The majority of the top English-language news sites in the world saw visits fall in February 2025, with just six recording web traffic higher than in January.
annotations.reason: Offers context on the general trend of web traffic changes among top news sites.

annotations.paragraph: Month-on-month growth was seen at US political news site The Hill (48 million visits, up 17%) and the Associated Press (139.9 million, up 6%), followed by Canadian sites CBC (74.4 million, up 6%) and Reuters (109.8 million, up 5%) and Indian ones Indian Express (109.1 million, up 3%) and News18 (164 million, up 2%).
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on month-on-month growth for several news sites, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: All other top titles – including every UK-based site in the top 50 – lost traffic. The sharpest drop was at another US current affairs brand, CBS News (87 million, down 25% month-on-month), followed by business publisher Forbes (137.9 million, down 24%) and India.com (143.5 million, down 24%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on traffic changes for major news sites, which is relevant to the article's focus on website rankings.

annotations.paragraph: Among the ten most-visited English-language news sites in the world every brand lost traffic compared to February. The biggest fall was at the BBC (still the world’s most popular English language news website), where visits fell 14% from more than a billion in January to 991.9 million last month. CNN (487.2 million, down 13%) was the next hardest-hit, followed by the UK’s Daily Mail (248.4 million, down 12%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides detailed information on traffic declines for top news sites, directly contributing to the article's main topic.

annotations.paragraph: The shallowest month-on-month declines were seen at Fox News (289.8 million, down 5%), People magazine (186 million, down 6%) and aggregator MSN (526.2 million, down 7%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers specific data on traffic changes for certain news sites, which is relevant to the article's focus on website rankings.

annotations.paragraph: Indian news sites have risen up the charts rapidly over the last year and now make up 11 of the top 50 and a quarter of the top 20 titles. CNN affiliate News18 had the most visits of these Indian sites in February, ranking 12th overall, and was followed by India Times (162.1 million) at 13th.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about the rise of Indian news sites in the rankings, contributing to the article's main topic.

annotations.paragraph: India.com, the 15th-most visited site in the month, also saw the greatest year-on-year growth of any top-50 publisher, increasing its visits 191% compared with February 2024. It was followed by the AP (up 71%) and publishing platform Substack (112 million visits, up 59%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on significant growth for certain news sites, which is relevant to the article's focus on website rankings.

annotations.paragraph: Among the top ten largest sites half grew year-on-year, despite their month-on-month falls. The largest growth was recorded by The New York Times (616.1 million, up 6%) followed by People (up 4%), the BBC (up 4%), Fox News (289.8 million, up 2%) and CNN (487.2 million, up 1%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on the growth of major news websites, directly related to the article's focus on popular news sites.

annotations.paragraph: The Daily Mail, meanwhile, saw the largest fall, dropping 19% but remaining in the top ten at eighth place. It was followed by MSN (down 7%), The Guardian (300.6 million, down 2%), and aggregators Yahoo Finance (227.3 million, down 2%) and Google News (313.8 million, down 1%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on the decline of certain news websites, relevant to the article's focus on popular news sites.

annotations.paragraph: Despite their rise in 2024, several Indian sites were also among the largest fallers year-on-year in February. The biggest decline compared with February 2024 was seen at India Today (67.5 million, down 36%), while fellow Indian sites Livemint (60.5 million, down 35%), News18 (down 23%) and Rediff (53.3 million, down 19%) all appeared among the ten largest losers of traffic.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on the decline of Indian news websites, relevant to the article's focus on popular news sites.

annotations.paragraph: Other notable sites to shed visitors year-on-year included Business Insider (68.1 million, down 35%), UK tabloids The Sun (53 million, down 29%) and Daily Mirror (49.5 million, down 29%) and Huffpost (49.8 million, down 22%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on the decline of various news websites, relevant to the article's focus on popular news sites.

annotations.paragraph: India.com was the fastest-growing top 50 global English-language news website in December.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on the growth of a news website, relevant to the article's focus on popular news sites.

annotations.paragraph: Its 177% year-on-year growth put it just outside the top ten with 188m visits according to Similarweb.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on a site's growth and ranking.

annotations.paragraph: Overall there are 11 India-based sites in the top 50 compared with nine UK-based websites and 24 US-based ones. India.com was launched 14 years ago and offers readers the option of viewing it in English or Hindi.
annotations.reason: Gives context on the geographical distribution of top sites.

annotations.paragraph: Among the 50 most-visited English-language news sites in the world last month, the three largest month-on-month increases were seen at CBS News (116.2 million, up 39%), global news agency Reuters (104.9 million, up 25%) and the Associated Press (132.6 million, up 23%).
annotations.reason: Lists specific sites with significant traffic increases.

annotations.paragraph: The Washington Post (112.8 million, up 17%), NBC News (110.3 million, up 21%) and CNN (556.6 million, up 12%) were all also among the ten-fastest growing sites compared to December 2024.
annotations.reason: Provides data on the growth of major news sites.

annotations.paragraph: Other sites in the top ten fastest-growing list included publishing platform Substack (115.6 million, up 22%), Indian broadcaster NDTV (130.1 million, up 16%) and British opinion-led broadcaster GB News (50.1 million, up 18%), which in January re-appeared in the global top 50 after previously spending two months on the chart at the start of 2024.
annotations.reason: Details additional fast-growing sites and their rankings.

annotations.paragraph: Each of the ten most-visited news sites in January saw visits increase compared with December, with CNN, The Guardian (323.3 million, up 11%) and People magazine (197.3 million, up 10%) the biggest beneficiaries.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on traffic increases for top news sites, relevant to the ranking.

annotations.paragraph: Compared with January last year, however, the picture was more mixed, with almost half of the top 50 recording a year-on-year decline in visits.
annotations.reason: Offers context on year-on-year traffic changes, relevant to understanding trends.

annotations.paragraph: The biggest grower compared with last January was India.com (187.7 million, up 177%), one of several Indian publishers to have worked their way up the chart in 2024. It was followed by the Associated Press (up 57%), Substack (53%), CBS News (30.5%) and NBC News (110.3 million, up 21%).
annotations.reason: Lists specific sites with significant growth, relevant to the ranking and trends.

annotations.paragraph: Mirroring the broader top 50, among the ten most-visited sites six publishers gained traffic year-on-year while four lost it. The biggest growth was at The New York Times (671.1 million, up 12%), followed by People (10.1%), CNN (8.7%), the BBC (1.1 billion, up 7.9%) and aggregator Yahoo Finance (252.6 million, up 7.2%). Another aggregator, Google News (351.8 million), recorded a 0.7% rise.
annotations.reason: Provides detailed data on traffic changes for top sites, relevant to the ranking.

annotations.paragraph: Year-on-year the Daily Mail (282.9 million) saw the greatest fall among the top ten, shedding 15.3% of its traffic compared to last January despite a 3% uptick compared with December 2024. It was followed by MSN (565.5 million, down 9%), The Guardian (323.3 million, down 6%) and Fox News (306.2 million, down 3%).
annotations.reason: Details significant traffic declines for specific sites, relevant to the ranking.

annotations.paragraph: The biggest year-on-year drops overall came at Indian news sites IndiaToday.in (73.7 million, down 40%) and LiveMint.com (66.1 million, down 37%). Significant falls were also registered at un-paywalled UK news sites The Sun (60.6 million, down 29%), the Daily Mirror (57.7 million, down 26%) and the Daily Mail (282.9 million, down 15%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on the year-on-year traffic drops for several major news sites, contributing to the article's focus on web traffic trends.

annotations.paragraph: Month-on-month only one site, the New York Post (143.5 million) lost double-digit percentage points of traffic, recording 10% fewer visits than in December. Indian news sites made up five of the ten sites to drop traffic month-on-month, led by OneIndia.com (102 million visits, down 7%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers detailed month-on-month traffic data for specific news sites, relevant to the article's examination of web traffic changes.

annotations.paragraph: Two-fifths of top English-language global news sites saw month-on-month web traffic declines of 10% or greater in December.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general statistic about traffic declines, which is relevant to the article's focus on web traffic trends.

annotations.paragraph: The largest falls were seen at the major US political and hard news sites who had been the biggest beneficiaries of November’s US election traffic boost.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives context about the traffic changes related to the US election, which is relevant to the article's theme of web traffic trends.

annotations.paragraph: They include NBC News (91.5 million visits in December, down 46.5% from November), the Associated Press (108.1 million, down 39.5%) and CBS News (83.9 million, down 25.7%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on traffic declines for major US news sites, contributing to the article's focus on web traffic trends.

annotations.paragraph: Overall 36 of the top 50 sites in the world saw fewer visits in December than in November. The picture was more mixed when compared against December 2023, however, with 23 of the top 50 gaining traffic year-on-year.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on traffic changes for the top 50 sites, which is relevant to the article's focus on popular news websites.

annotations.paragraph: Month-on-month, the majority of the ten most-visited sites lost traffic, with CNN (497.3 million, down 25%) falling fastest followed by Fox News (278.7 million, down 19.8%), The New York Times (633.5 million, down 13.8%) and The Guardian (292.5 million, down 12.4%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives detailed statistics on traffic changes for the most-visited sites, directly contributing to the article's main topic.

annotations.paragraph: The Daily Mail (274.6 million, up 5.8% month-on-month) and India.com (188.8 million, up 9.4%) were among the few top ten sites to grow visits compared with November.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific examples of sites that increased traffic, which is relevant to the article's focus on news website rankings.

annotations.paragraph: The greatest monthly growth among the broader top 50 came at sports news site Athlon Sports (57 million visits), which spent 2024 rising up the US top 50 and in December appeared on the global top 50 for the first time. The site saw 38% month-on-month growth in December. It was followed by the UK’s Daily Express (59.6 million, up 17.6%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights significant growth in specific sites, contributing to the narrative of changing news website rankings.

annotations.paragraph: Athlon Sports was also the fastest-growing site on the top 50 year-on-year, increasing its visits 353% compared with December 2023. The second biggest growth year-on-year was Indian news site India.com (up 146.6%), which has entered the top ten global English-language news sites for the first time.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides year-on-year growth data for specific sites, relevant to the article's focus on news website popularity.

annotations.paragraph: Despite their month-on-month visitor contractions, there was strong annual growth at the AP (up 50.8% year-on-year) and NBC News (up 20.4%), as well as other large publishers ABC News (64.5 million, up 36.6%) and The New York Times (up 9.6%).
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on annual growth for major news sites, relevant to the ranking of popular news websites.

annotations.paragraph: CNN (2.9%) and the BBC (1.1 billion, up 1.8%) also saw modest annual growth, but half the ten biggest sites by visits lost traffic compared with December 2023. These included the Daily Mail (down 18.9%), Fox News (down 10.1%) and The Guardian (down 9.6%).
annotations.reason: Offers specific information on traffic changes for major news sites, relevant to the article's focus on website rankings.

annotations.paragraph: The five sharpest year-on-year declines were all felt at British and Indian news sites. The fastest faller was India Today (74.1 million, down 37.7% year-on-year), followed by Live Mint (63.6 million, down 35.6%), The Sun (60.3 million, down 33%), CNN affiliate News18 (167.1 million, down 28.8%) and the Daily Mirror (56.4 million, down 24.8%).
annotations.reason: Provides detailed data on significant declines in traffic for specific news sites, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: American hard news providers saw visits surge in November amid the 2024 US presidential election and its aftermath, data from Similarweb shows.
annotations.reason: Gives context on traffic surges related to a major event, relevant to understanding traffic trends.

annotations.paragraph: NBC News (170.9 million views) saw the biggest month-on-month traffic gain among the 50 most-visited English-language news sites in the world in November, growing 56.3%.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on traffic gains for a major news site, relevant to the article's focus on website rankings.

annotations.paragraph: Narrowly behind was news agency the Associated Press (178.8 million visits in November) up 56% compared with October.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on the Associated Press's web traffic, contributing to the article's focus on popular news websites.

annotations.paragraph: Both sites were also the fastest-growing sites year-on-year among the top 50, with the AP notching a 161.4% increase in its traffic compared to November 2023, and NBC up 120.9%. They were followed by another US hard news mainstay, ABC News (85.1 million visits, up 92.2% year-on-year and 19% month-on-month).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides detailed growth statistics for several major news sites, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Other websites to experience notable traffic surges in November included broadcasters Fox News (347.3 million, up 21.8% month-on-month), CBS News (112.8 million, up 19.7%) and CNN (662.8 million, up 11.5%), US paper of record The New York Times (734.8 million, up 11.6%) and agency Reuters (105.7 million, up 14.3%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph lists specific traffic data for several major news websites, directly relevant to the article's topic.

annotations.paragraph: There were month-on-month traffic declines at nearly half of the sites in the top 50, although they were relatively mild: of the 24 that dropped, nine saw visits dip by 2% or less and 17 by less than 5%. The biggest month-on-month traffic fall was at Huffpost (58.1 million visits, down 12% month-on-month), followed by Indian CNN affiliate News18 (185.9 million, down 11%).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on traffic declines, adding depth to the article's analysis of news website trends.

annotations.paragraph: Among only the ten biggest English-language news sites in the world, Fox News saw the strongest month-on-month growth in November, followed by USA Today (233.9 million, up 12%), The New York Times, CNN, The Guardian (333.8 million, up 4.1%) and the BBC (1.1 billion, up 3.3%), which remains the largest publisher on the ranking.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers specific growth data for the top ten news sites, relevant to the article's focus on popular news websites.

annotations.paragraph: Google News (326.3 million, down 4.7%) saw the biggest drop among the top ten, followed by fellow aggregator MSN (593.4 million, down 3.4%).
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on traffic changes for major news aggregators.

annotations.paragraph: After the AP, NBC and ABC, the biggest year-on-year growth in the global top 50 came at India.com (172.5 million, up 92%), one of several Indian news sites to have seen substantial growth in the past year. Politico (63.2 million, up 60.6% year-on-year), creator platform Substack (94.3 million, up 65.9%) and Newsweek (128.9 million, up 65.9%) were also among the ten fastest-growers.
annotations.reason: Lists specific sites with significant growth, relevant to the article's focus on top news websites.

annotations.paragraph: Among the top ten sites USA Today saw by far the biggest year-on-year growth, with visits increasing 65.4% compared to November last year. It was followed by The New York Times (up 35.1%), CNN (up 34.1%) and Fox News (17.2%).
annotations.reason: Details specific growth figures for major news sites, relevant to the article's topic.

annotations.paragraph: Two sites in the top ten lost traffic compared with a year ago: Google News (down 1.5%) and DailyMail.co.uk (259.6 million, down 16.9%). The Mail is among several UK tabloids to have taken a traffic hit from recent Google algorithm changes — rival publisher The Sun (60.9 million) recorded the second-steepest overall year-on-year traffic drop in November, with visits falling 21.1%.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on traffic declines and context about algorithm impacts.

annotations.paragraph: Overall nine publishers in the top 50 saw year-on-year traffic decline. The largest was at News Corp’s news.com.au (69.5 million, down 21.9%), with double-digit drops also seen at another UK tabloid, the Mirror (57.5 million, down 14%) and Indian sites News18 (down 16.6%), India Today (93.6 million, down 15%) and Live Mint (75.1 million, down 14.7%).
annotations.reason: Lists specific sites with traffic declines, relevant to the article's focus on top news websites.

annotations.paragraph: Most of the world’s top 50 English-language news sites lost traffic year-on-year in October, but saw month-on-month growth after two months of decline.
annotations.reason: Provides context on traffic trends for top news sites, relevant to the article's focus on website rankings.

annotations.paragraph: Newsweek (131.6 million visits in October 2024), which has repeatedly ranked as the fastest-growing news site year-on-year in 2024, again topped the chart for visitor growth, seeing a 105.6% increase compared with October 2023.
annotations.reason: Offers specific data on Newsweek's growth, contributing to the article's focus on popular news sites.

annotations.paragraph: It was followed by India.com (191.2 million, up 86% year-on-year), and publishing platform Substack (86.9 million, up 44.4%), which may have been a beneficiary of interest in the run-up to the US election on 5 November.
annotations.reason: Provides specific growth data for India.com and Substack, relevant to the article's focus on news site rankings.

annotations.paragraph: Other US hard news outlets, including CBS News (94.3 million, up 26.3% year-on-year), ABC News (71.5 million, up 23.1%) and the Associated Press (114.6 million, up 13.8%) also saw year-on-year growth.
annotations.reason: Gives specific growth figures for US news outlets, relevant to the article's focus on news site rankings.

annotations.paragraph: But among the top 50, 31 publishers saw their total visits drop compared with October 2023. The biggest fall was at Middle Eastern-focused world news publisher Al Jazeera (66.2 million), where visits fell more than a third compared with last year.
annotations.reason: Provides data on traffic declines, including specific figures for Al Jazeera, relevant to the article's focus on news site rankings.

annotations.paragraph: News Corp Australia’s News.com.au (68.9 million, down 24%), as well as British mass-market publications Mail Online (268 million, down 28%), the Daily Mirror (62.4 million, down 23.5%) and The Sun (61.6 million, down 23.4%) were also among the biggest fallers.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on traffic declines for major news sites, relevant to the ranking of top news websites.

The greatest increase in visits came at The New York Times (546 million), which grew its traffic by 6.3% compared with October 2023, followed by Yahoo Finance (229.4 million, up 4.6%) and aggregator MSN (614 million, up 3.5%).
annotations.reason: Offers specific growth data for top news sites, directly related to the article's focus on website rankings.

annotations.paragraph: The only sites to grow their web traffic month-on-month were CBS News (102.3 million visits, up 18% month-on-month) and India.com (140.54 million, up 42%).
annotations.reason: Gives specific data on sites that grew month-on-month, relevant to the article's focus on traffic trends.

annotations.reason: Provides specific data on traffic changes for major US news sites, relevant to the ranking of top news websites.

annotations.paragraph: Last month English language news sites outside India saw a sharp pull-back coming out neof an eventful July that saw the opening of the Paris Olympics, Joe Biden dropping out of the presidential race and an assassination attempt on Donald Trump. Indian sites generally fared well, however, increasing traffic compared with July or remaining largely stable.
annotations.reason: Offers context on global news site traffic trends and specific events impacting traffic, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: This month India.com, OneIndia.com and IndianExpress.com were among the ten sites with the most growth (or the least shrinkage) month-on-month, but several Indian sites were also the fastest droppers, including The Hindu newspaper (72.2 million, down 17.6% month-on-month), LiveMint.com (69.1 million, down 17%) and NDTV (102.6 million, down 25.8%).
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on Indian news sites' traffic changes, relevant to the global ranking of news websites.

annotations.reason: Details significant traffic declines for specific news sites, relevant to the article's focus on top news websites.

They were, again, joined by Indian news sites Live Mint (down 26.8% year-on-year), India Today (down 26.8%), The Hindu (down 20%), NDTV (down 17.2%) and Rediff (61 million visits, down 14.2% year-on-year) also in the top ten.
annotations.reason: Provides year-on-year traffic data for major news sites, relevant to the article's focus on news website rankings.

annotations.paragraph: Similarweb generates its traffic data by applying machine learning and modelling to the statistically representative datasets that the company collects. Datasets are based on direct measurement (i.e. websites and apps that choose to share first-party analytics with Similarweb); contributory networks that aggregate device data; partnerships and public data extraction from websites and apps. The sites in the list are based on Similarweb’s classification of news and media publishers, although Press Gazette refines the list to exclude some sites with a less news-based focus.
annotations.reason: Explains the methodology behind the traffic data, relevant to understanding the rankings.

annotations.paragraph: CNN was the fastest-growing top 10 news website in the world month-on-month in January, according to Press Gazette’s updated ranking.
